docs.abstract: Google has released details on a security system it is using to defend the Android app store from software that can harm its users. Called Bouncer, the service analyzes apps for suspicious activity and flags them before they have a chance to get into the store.

docs.snippet: Google has released details on a security system it is using to defend the Android app store from software that can harm its users. Called Bouncer, the service analyzes apps for suspicious activity and flags them before they have a chance to get i...
docs.lead_paragraph: Google has released details of a security system it is using to protect the Android app store from malicious software. Called Bouncer, the service analyzes apps and flags those with suspicious code before they have a chance to get into the store, the company said.

docs.snippet: LIBRESCO--Len. Husband, father and grandfather, citizen of the world, consummate teacher, in love with ideas, provocateur and pundit, dear to all who knew and loved him, died Thursday, January 12, 2012 at the age of 78. He died as he lived, with c...
docs.lead_paragraph: LIBRESCO--Len. Husband, father and grandfather, citizen of the world, consummate teacher, in love with ideas, provocateur and pundit, dear to all who knew and loved him, died Thursday, January 12, 2012 at the age of 78. He died as he lived, with courage and humility, drawing upon an inner strength that never failed to inspire and amaze. Len was born and raised in New York City where his education included The BronxHigh School of Science, Queens College, Columbia University, and most importantly, the incredible libraries, museums, theatre, opera, and melting pot of New York City. The child of immigrants, Jenny and Zol, and brother to Emile, he inhaled the ideas and promises that America offered. Len later pursued his doctorate at the University of California, Davis, where he met Marilyn, who would become his wife and partner for the next 43 years. Len earned a BA, two master's degrees, and PhD, abd. He was a student of the world, studying art, languages, history, and most recently, ukulele. There was never a need for an encyclopedia for Len was the Encyclopedia Britannica; Google before there was Google. Len launched his career at the United Nations, and spent over ten years with the Peace Corps directing programs in India, Iran, Micronesia, and the Solomon Islands. Later he served as Executive Director of the International Institute of the East Bay, after a decade as Director of Human Resources for Icore, International in Silicon Valley. Len was a quiet force who offered books, ideas, and encouragement to any who crossed his path. He will be loved and remembered by his wife, his children and their families, his grandchildren, his brother-in-law, his nephew and nieces and their families, and by all he touched and nurtured. For details on a memorial, please contact the family at librescomemorial@gmail.com.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIBRESCO, LEN

headline.main: Start-Up Nicira Plans to Disrupt Networking Giants

docs.abstract: A small company called Nicira and a few other scrappy players are pursuing what is called software-defined networking. Software-defined networking is similar to server virtualization, and it is quite likely to be bad news for networking giants like Cisco and Juniper. If proprietary systems can be blended, and cheap chips used in place of custom ships, prices for the gear will probably drop.

docs.snippet: Video of a day devoted to living thoughtfully, at Google headquarters in California....

headline.main: On Google's Lunch Menu: Mindful Eating

docs.abstract: Video of a day devoted to living thoughtfully, at Google headquarters in California.

docs.snippet: Video of a day devoted to living thoughtfully, at Google headquarters in California....
docs.lead_paragraph: Last September, hundreds of Google employees showed up to experience a day of mindfulness with Thich Nhat Hanh, the Vietnamese Zen monk, teacher and author. The day included a lunch devoted to mindful eating, a practice explored in this week's Dining cover story. The event was so well received that it has since evolved into a monthly gathering on the Google campus in Mountain View, Calif. Olivia Wu, an executive chef with the company, said the silent lunch helps to restore busy, tired minds and "and revives the corporate culture of innovation, community and doing the right thing."

headline.main: On Google's Lunch Menu: Mindful Eating

docs.abstract: Video of a day devoted to living thoughtfully, at Google headquarters in California.

docs.snippet: In Tuesday's New York Times, Steve Lohr reports on Stephen Wolfram, a 52-year-old scientist, software designer, entrepreneur and winner of the MacArthur prize, who three years ago created a new kind of search engine, Wolfram Alpha. Unlike Google o...

headline.main: Wolfram, a Search Engine, Finds Answers Within Itself

docs.abstract: In Tuesday's New York Times, Steve Lohr reports on Stephen Wolfram, a 52-year-old scientist, software designer, entrepreneur and winner of the MacArthur prize, who three years ago created a new kind of search engine, Wolfram Alpha. Unlike Google or Microsoft's Bing, Wolfram Alpha does not forage the Web, but culls its own painstakingly curated database to find answers. There was initial skepticism, but the technology has come a long way.

docs.snippet: That Google+ may have certain advantages in its feature set matters little to Nick Roulleau if it can't produce bodies....
docs.lead_paragraph: Last week, I posted about Ryan Negri, founder of high-end cell-phone vendor Negri Electronics, who has found Google+ to be a better way than Facebook to reach and communicate with customers. He especially likes (or should I say +1s?) Google+'s "circles," which let him segment his customers for more tailored messaging, while also motivating them to interact with him. In this post I want to describe another reason Mr. Negri thinks Google+ provides a real edge -- and also present the point of view of a business owner who disagrees.

headline.main: Debating the Merits of Facebook and Google+

docs.abstract: That Google+ may have certain advantages in its feature set matters little to Nick Roulleau if it can't produce bodies.

docs.snippet: In a move that is likely to rattle its competitors is search and browsing, Google is expected to introduce its Chrome browser for Android 4.0 phones and tablets on Tuesday. Chrome's mobile browser is as speedy as its desktop counterpart, but incor...
docs.lead_paragraph: The browser wars just got interesting again.

headline.main: Google Makes Its Chrome Browser Mobile

docs.abstract: In a move that is likely to rattle its competitors is search and browsing, Google is expected to introduce its Chrome browser for Android 4.0 phones and tablets on Tuesday. Chrome's mobile browser is as speedy as its desktop counterpart, but incorporates syncing capabilities too. Google still trails Microsoft in desktop browsing, but Tuesday's announcement is likely to give Google a leg up in mobile browsing, where no clear leader has emerged.

docs.snippet: What rules, if any, do you think should govern how companies collect and use personal and aggregate data?...
docs.lead_paragraph: Facebook has swelled to an estimated 845 million users, who typically share everything from their last name to their favorite movies -- even phone numbers and e-mails. What users may not realize is that advertisers then use this information to customize what ads appear on a user's page. What sort of impression do you think advertisers and companies might have of you, based on how you use Facebook and search engines like Google?

headline.main: What Story Does Your Personal Data Tell?

docs.abstract: What rules, if any, do you think should govern how companies collect and use personal and aggregate data?

docs.snippet: Billy Parrott was on the way to a peek at a little treasure when the truth came out.     ''It looks like he checked out stuff from the library and never returned it,'' said Mr. Parrott, who is in charge of the New York Public Library's collection ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Billy Parrott was on the way to a peek at a little treasure when the truth came out. ''It looks like he checked out stuff from the library and never returned it,'' said Mr. Parrott, who is in charge of the New York Public Library's collection of prints and postcards. ''We can only assume he paid his fine for things not returned.''

headline.main: 1.2 Million Images, Google Search Not Required

docs.abstract: City Room blog; Billy Parrot presides over New York Public Library's collection of 1.2 million prints and postcards, largest circulating picture collection in the world; collection, begun in 1915, is favorite resource for artists, art directors and scenic designers. Photos (M)

docs.snippet: SAN FRANCISCO - Google, Facebook, Microsoft and Amazon already turn millions of computers into single clouds of supermachines, managing the flow between personal computers of cat videos, e-mails and the president's recent chat on Google Plus.     ...
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO - Google, Facebook, Microsoft and Amazon already turn millions of computers into single clouds of supermachines, managing the flow between personal computers of cat videos, e-mails and the president's recent chat on Google Plus. Millions more of these computer servers figure out what to sell you while you browse the Web. These global systems work only because of something called virtualization, a kind of software that tricks one server into doing the tasks of several. The cost savings and flexibility revolutionized the data management business, since virtualized machines can run on cheap semiconductors.

headline.main: A Start-Up Has Plans to Displace the Giants of Networking

docs.abstract: Small start-up company Nicira, along with a few other scrappy players, is pursuing what is called software-defined networking, which should cut costs and make equipment more efficient; it claims savings of up to $37 million in a data center with 40,000 servers, and 50 percent cost reductions in setting up the fastest networks. Photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Less than a year ago, Google made a deal with the government. It promised the Federal Trade Commission it would seek its users' consent before changing the way any Google products share personal information.

headline.main: Consumer Rights Group Says Google Broke its Promise

docs.abstract: A consumer rights group says that Google has violated its deal with the government about getting user consent before making changes to privacy policies. Google says that it is making things simpler, not breaking its promise. The Electronic Privacy Information Center wants the Federal Trade Commission to hold Google to its promise.

headline.main: Yahoo Board Shaken Up In a Push For Revival

docs.abstract: Yahoo board is being overhauled, replacing nearly half its directors as company is under pressure from shareholders to improve returns and revive its fortunes; Yahoo's chairman Roy J Bostock writes in a letter to shareholders that neither he nor the company's three longest-serving directors will stand for re-election; board has elected two new directors, Maynard Webb Jr and Alfred Amoroso, with plans to search for more. Or to learn about something that I, myself, don't know. I know you're shocked, but believe me, it's entirely possible.

No hacking is required, and it can take a thief just minutes to start spending your cash.

docs.snippet: Also, the financial windfall of "Charlie Bit My Finger," the dust-up between Felix Salmon and Michael Kinsley and Bloomberg Businessweek goes inside the Murdoch hacking war room....
docs.lead_paragraph: Google is developing a home entertainment device that will wirelessly connect with other home equipment, bringing the company "more broadly into consumer electronics," David Streitfeld and Nicole Perlroth report. It exists in prototype and will be tested in employees' homes this summer; the initial purpose of the device will be for streaming music, but its eventual use could be much wider. The news, which was first reported by the tech-news site GigaOM, had been kept secret and emerged from a filing with the Federal Communications Commission.

headline.main: Daily Report: An Entertainment Device From Google

docs.abstract: Google is at work on a home entertainment device, report David Streitfeld and Nicole Perlroth on Friday in The New York Times. The device, a prototype, will eventually be sold under the Google brand, and is the company's most significant push into hardware. The initial purpose of the device will be for streaming music, but eventually its use could be much wider.

docs.snippet: Google is at work on a home entertainment device, report David Streitfeld and Nicole Perlroth on Friday in The New York Times. The device, a prototype, will eventually be sold under the Google brand, and is the company's most significant push into...
docs.lead_paragraph: Google is at work on a home entertainment device, report David Streitfeld and Nicole Perlroth on Friday in The New York Times. The device, which would carry the Google brand name, would be used for streaming music throughout the home, but eventually it could have a broader use.  The device is the company's most significant push into hardware, and is likely to be manufactured by the handset maker Motorola Mobility, which Google is purchasing in a $12.5 billion deal.

headline.main: Daily Report: An Entertainment Device From Google

headline.print_headline: An ‘Entertainment Device’ Is Expected From Google

docs.abstract: Google is said to be developing a home entertainment device, a move into hardware that will bring the company more broadly into consumer electronics; Motorola Mobility is likely to build the device, as Google's $12.5 billion acquisition of the company is set to close; initial purpose of the device is for streaming music, but the eventual use could be much wider.

docs.snippet: Yahoo's drive to revive its business hit major roadblocks on Tuesday, as the company's talks to sell back most of its stakes in its Asian partners collapsed and a big investor unveiled plans to mount a board fight.     The developments raised ques...
docs.lead_paragraph: Yahoo's drive to revive its business hit major roadblocks on Tuesday, as the company's talks to sell back most of its stakes in its Asian partners collapsed and a big investor unveiled plans to mount a board fight. The developments raised questions about whether Yahoo would be able to reverse years of missteps and make itself relevant in an Internet landscape now dominated by Google and Facebook. They also put additional pressure on the company's new chief executive, Scott Thompson, to provide a clear vision of what the new Yahoo will look like.

headline.main: Yahoo Faces Stalled Deal And Fight Over Board

docs.abstract: Yahoo's talks to sell back most of its stakes in its Asian partners collapse as Third Point, a hedge fund that is one of the company's biggest investors, unveils plans to mount a board fight, stalling efforts to revive the business; developments raise question of whether Yahoo can reverse years of missteps and make itself relevant; it is unclear why talks between Yahoo and Alibaba and Yahoo Japan's majority owner Softbank collapsed, with both sides weeks away from announcing a deal. Photos (M)

byline.original: By MICHAEL J. DE LA MERCED and EVELYN M. RUSLI

headline.main: F.T.C. Finds Privacy Problems With Apps for Children

docs.abstract: The Federal Trade Commission issued a report saying that makers of mobile applications aimed at children are not clear about their handling of privacy issues and the data their apps collect. It placed much of the blame on Google and Apple for the way they manage their app stores.

docs.snippet: For years, people looking for a real browsing experience on Android phones and tablets have been left pecking through something Google called ''Browser'' - an open-source-based browser that wasn't quite horrible but wasn't quite great, either. Now...
docs.lead_paragraph: For years, people looking for a real browsing experience on Android phones and tablets have been left pecking through something Google called ''Browser'' - an open-source-based browser that wasn't quite horrible but wasn't quite great, either. Now, for a certain lucky few, Google's own browser, Chrome, is available on Android devices and it's a very nice upgrade. First, the good news: Google Chrome is a considerable improvement over the old browser and features a ''stack'' system for collecting and sorting Web pages. It supports tabbed browsing on larger screens and the stacks let you organize pages on a phone or minitablet.

headline.main: Chrome Comes to Android, Just a Little at a Time

docs.snippet: Searching Google for images of a person, place or thing is easy enough by just typing keywords into the search box. Google also has a feature that actually lets you search for information with a particular image itself - and get back results relat...
docs.lead_paragraph: Searching Google for images of a person, place or thing is easy enough by just typing keywords into the search box. Google also has a feature that actually lets you search for information with a particular image itself - and get back results related to the picture or its contents. To search by image, go to images.google.com and click on the camera icon in the search box. You can choose to paste in an image's URL or upload one from your computer to search; Chrome and Firefox users can drag a loose image from the desktop into the search box to kick off the quest.

headline.main: Tip Of The Week

docs.abstract: Personal Q&A Tip of the Week notes that Google has a feature that lets the user search for information with a particular image itself, and get back results related to the picture or its contents. (S)

headline.main: An E-Mail App Arrives for the BlackBerry Tablet
headline.print_headline: An E-Mail App Arrives For the BlackBerry Tablet

docs.abstract: Research in Motion finally brings e-mail to its tablet computer, the BlackBerry PlayBook; initially, the device could only send or receive e-mails by being connected to a BlackBerry phone; upgrade also allows the PlayBook to run some apps developed for devices that use Google's Android operating system, integrates information and messages from social media sites, and allows for use of BlackBerry phones as a physical keyboard for the tablet through a wireless connection.

docs.abstract: Mozilla, which makes the open-source Firefox browser, has been developing its own smartphone operating system to compete with the likes of Apple and Google. Its mission, Mozilla says, is to "give developers freedom without gatekeepers." It has announced its own online store, where Web-based apps can be sold.

docs.abstract: Google will start selling eyeglasses that will project information, entertainment and ads onto the lenses; glasses are not being designed to be worn constantly, but will be more like smartphones, used when needed, with the lenses serving as a kind of see-through computer monitor; however, questions have been raised on how privacy will be regulated.

docs.lead_paragraph: In my This Week in Small Business post on Monday, I quoted a social media expert, Krista Neher, who had written a blog post about why businesses should be using Google+. As a follow-up, I went back to Ms. Neher with a few questions. Q.With all the social media options available, who has time for all of them? And why would someone focus on Google+ when there are so many more people on Facebook?

headline.main: Daily Report: Google's Big-Name Lobbyist

docs.abstract: Google increasingly finds itself under scrutiny from lawmakers in Washington. Now it is hoping that a former lawmaker will help out on that front. The company has hired Susan Molinari, the former Republican congresswoman from New York, as its Washington lobbyist, Eric Lichtblau reports on the Caucus blog.

docs.snippet: Movie attendance hit a 16-year low in 2011. Star wattage continues to dim. DVD sales keep plunging. But Hollywood has a noticeable spring in its step....

headline.seo: Web Deals Cheer Hollywood, Despite a Drop in Moviegoers
headline.main: Web Deals Cheer Hollywood, Despite Drop in Moviegoers
headline.print_headline: Web Deals Cheer Hollywood, Despite a Drop in Moviegoers

docs.abstract: Hollywood announces several plans aimed at curbing low movie attendance and plunging DVD sales; plans include a Google-developed home entertainment device and several new online streaming services; taken together, moves mean no supplier will have a monopoly over the distribution of films and television on the Internet, allowing Hollywood better leverage in setting the prices for its content.

docs.snippet: Andy Rubin, the head of Google's Android efforts, acknowledges that, unlike smartphones, tablets running Android have yet to gain much traction among consumers. He vows that that will change this year as Google makes more of a concerted effort to ...

headline.main: Android Tablets: Catching Up in 2012

docs.abstract: Andy Rubin, the head of Google's Android efforts, acknowledges that, unlike smartphones, tablets running Android have yet to gain much traction among consumers. He vows that that will change this year as Google makes more of a concerted effort to build an ecosystem of app developers for the tablets, which will spur greater consumer interest.

docs.snippet: Mozilla's mission since its outset in 1998, first as a software project and later as a foundation and company, has been to provide open technology that challenges a dominant corporate product.     Microsoft and its Internet Explorer browser was Mo...
docs.lead_paragraph: Mozilla's mission since its outset in 1998, first as a software project and later as a foundation and company, has been to provide open technology that challenges a dominant corporate product. Microsoft and its Internet Explorer browser was Mozilla's original target. Today, Mozilla sees the rise of Apple and Google in mobile software as a ''threat to the open Web,'' said Jay Sullivan, vice president for products at the Mozilla Corporation.

headline.main: Mozilla Sets Its Sights On Apps

docs.abstract: Bits blog notes Mozilla announces a step in its smartphone strategy, Mozilla Marketplace, which will begin accepting Web-based apps. (M)

docs.snippet: SAN FRANCISCO -- In 2000, when Google could count its employees by the dozen, it adopted its now famous mantra: Don't be evil.     Google considered it such a cornerstone of its operating philosophy that it was included in the S-1 filing to the Se...
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO -- In 2000, when Google could count its employees by the dozen, it adopted its now famous mantra: Don't be evil. Google considered it such a cornerstone of its operating philosophy that it was included in the S-1 filing to the Securities and Exchange Commission in 2004 when it went public.

headline.main: Disruptions: Growing Too Big For a Conscience

docs.abstract: Nick Bilton Disruptions column observes Google came up with the slogan 'Don't be evil' in 2000, but now the company, with $38 billion in revenue, has had to counter complaints that it invaded consumer privacy; says what Google officials refer to as stumbles are concerted efforts to compete. (M)

headline.main: Google's Schmidt Predicts an Android for Everyone on the Planet

docs.abstract: Eric Schmidt is hoping Android will get the whole world onto the Internet. Mr. Schmidt, chairman and former chief executive of Google, said in a speech at the Mobile World Congress in Barcelona that although the conference had focused on high-powered devices and speedy connections, those innovations were available only to a privileged few.

headline.main: One Year Later, Nokia and Microsoft Deliver

docs.abstract: Nokia and Microsoft deliver on the promise of their partnership to produce new smartphones, exceeding their own predictions, and by most estimations, the expectations of many in an industry dominated by Apple and Samsung, whose phones run Google's Android operating system, reports Kevin J. O'Brien on Tuesday in The New York Times.

headline.print_headline: One Year Later, Nokia And Microsoft Deliver

docs.abstract: Nokia and Microsoft, one year after start of their software alliance, have exceeded their own predictions and, by most estimations, the expectations of many; Nokia introduces new cellphones and will open new Windows online marketplaces in 28 countries by March.

docs.snippet: A.M.D. buys a hot start-up, SeaMicro, that makes "microservers" for the data centers of the National Security Agency, Facebook and Google. The chip maker will use SeaMicro's technology to offer customers like Hewlett-Packard and Dell small and ene...

headline.main: A.M.D. Buying SeaMicro for $334 Million

docs.abstract: A.M.D. buys a hot start-up, SeaMicro, that makes "microservers" for the data centers of the National Security Agency, Facebook and Google. The chip maker will use SeaMicro's technology to offer customers like Hewlett-Packard and Dell small and energy-efficient systems they can put into their servers for the corporate cloud. It is the boldest move yet by A.M.D.'s new chief executive, who came on last August.

docs.snippet: The statement, just days before the new policy was to go into effect, is the latest hurdle the company has faced in Europe....
docs.lead_paragraph: The statement, just days before the new policy was to go into effect, is the latest hurdle the company has faced in Europe.

headline.main: France Says Google Privacy Plan Likely Violates European Law
headline.print_headline: France Says Google Plan Violates Law

docs.abstract: French data protection authority, the National Commission for Computing and Civil Liberties, says that Google's new privacy policy appears to violate European Union law; agency says that policy, billed as a way to streamline and simplify privacy practices employed worldwide across 60 different online services, is murky in the details of how Google would use private data.
